title: I appreciate Gangplank nerfs and we all agree something needs to be done..
body:
But I still completely disagree with these nerfs. You're just going to keep nerfing him until his cooldowns are too high, his mana costs are too high and his base damages are too low. You'll basically be doing exactly what you did to old GP during meta golem where you kept constantly nerfing him. The difference is, I don't think he needs these nerfs. It won't change anything, he will still be picked in almost every competitive game. 

I play GP and I can tell you the biggest problems with him are his bonus gold passive on his Q and his Q applying melee bandit gold. With these two things, he farms up so much gold just by existing. Even if he's getting zoned for a wave or two, he's still collecting some gold. And that's rare a champion can do that to be honest. He can sit back and just keep a barrel behind him and clear waves this way and not interact. There's nothing that can be done about that, GP will be a safe farmer no matter what. GPs ult will provide great zone control in teamfights no matter what. GP basically already has a free ticket to late game but I don't think you should complete remove his ability to have lane presence and make him a non interactive farmer either because that playstyle is extremely unhealthy.

What needs to be done is removing his bonus gold passive on Q and changing how his Q works with masteries like grasp and bandit, these are clearly ranged spells granting melee benefits and this shouldn't be the case. His Q's gold passive is what makes him impossible to shut down. Even when you have large leads by 2-3 kills on him, at best you're slightly ahead in gold. Between his barrels, ult and orange, snowballing on GP is almost impossible. And that shouldn't be a thing for a champion that scales so hard into late game. And these nerfs don't change that, they're just going to force him to be more farm heavy and non interactive and players will feel like they can't do anything to stop the GP train from going full force late game. 

Make him able to actually lose a lane significantly enough that he has to consider something other than farming two waves to make back up whatever deficit he had. This would be a much better change than what you're doing right now.

I agree with the Gold gain nerfs, but i disagree with the statement that his current nerfs are wrong.
The nerfs hit exatly where they should.
His early laneing gets less safe, between the higher mana costs on W and less base hp, you get more kill potential vs him, allowing to excert more early pressure against Gp.
Even without his extra gold, a well played GP would still be incredible safe becuase he can farm from range, gets good wavecontroll once trinity is completed and has his nope oragnes. Makeing his early a bit weaker goes hand in hand with your idea of lowering the 'free' gold he gets to make early advantages more meaningfull.
And the Ult nerf is really needed. That ult is absurd, and one of the main balance issues. There are other lategamescaleing champs that are decently save in lane and reliably reach their lategame point, but they sacrifice map preasure for it.
Gp has more map preasure than nearly any other champ in the early, without ever stopping to farm his lane for it. That ult on an lategame hyperscaler is just insane as it gives him so much impact even early in the game as he can deter dives on him, win many 1v1 all-ins with it, prevent crossmap plays and even creat crossmap plays.
All without ever leaving his lane.
It's just an instant fully global ult, and that's imo rather bad design, there is little to counter it. Other globals are either skillshots, have some other form of delay or are only semi-global, so you won't reach from top to bot. Karthus is BS aswell, but he atleast has 3 sec channle that can be interupted by death or hard CC.
But GPs ult has some meaningfull impactpac on any point of the map the very moment he presses the button, you can't avoid that first cluster at all, and hardly the second if it's centered on you, and 2 clusters already are amongst the highest basedamage for ults in the game(300 at rank 6+evt thunderlords)

Without the ult-nerf, GP would remain a monster, he might need slightly longer ti reach his mid-lategame powerspikes, but as long as his ult grants as much earlygame impact, that doesn't matter at all.

Hmm I disagree. Honestly no matter what you do, GP will always have the same play style (sitting on barrels, Q'ing the wave, and generally not fighting), and taking away the gold won't change that, so it doesnt solve the problem of interactivity.

As a Gangplank main, my opinion is that it is his game stalling techniques that are the problem. I think this contributes to what you call a "free ticket to late game." What I mean by this is his ability to 1-shot casters and 2-shot the whole wave after trinity. This severely limits the opportunity for tower-dives or just pressuring him under the turret, forcing you to try and freeze, but then he just farms safely from a distance anyway. It also makes Gangplank an effective counter to split-pushers like Trynd or Fiora who like to push waves in and then tower-dive, as he can stop them from getting to the tower at all.

This is not an easy problem to fix except by just straight up **making barrels do reduced damage to minions**. This would force him to farm individually with Q and melee autos more often when he's frozen out or forced under turret. Conversely he could use multiple barrels to clear the wave, which diminishes his ability to escape as he has less barrels on hand. It also gives incentive to use barrels against champs to try and whittle them down instead of just clearing the wave and running away because now he has to hang around the wave longer if he's being frozen out for example. Hopefully they could find a number where come late-game he is still able to siege and defend properly (he is a late-game champ after all), but make it so if he's behind to a strong laner in mid game he can't just blow up waves and run away. 

Honestly this might be totally wacky and nonsensical, but it's just my 2 cents as a guy who plays a ton of GP.

I think no champion should have mechanics that enable them to get extra Gold, with the exception of Draven perhaps. The thing is that getting free gold for doing something easy (farm minions in TF's case, farm with Q procs in GP's case) is just a bunch of hidden power that's hard to gauge by the opponent. I'm never quite sure just how much extra Gold TF has, for example. GP's is a bit more trackable since you can keep an eye on his Silver Serpent stash, but even there it shows that he's easily getting a Gold lead on anyone unless you have a significant CS advantage.

In GP's case I am more worried over his lane pattern, though. He basically is weak to all-in (even there, oranges help mitigate being caught out) but his barrel mechanic allows him to stand in Africa and still effectively farm due to the large range. He gets a movement speed bonus to boot, so trading with him after he blows a barrel on you becomes a tough sell due to his movement speed bonus and your movement speed penalty.

I think rather than his ult damage, I'd rather see the ult size nerfed. It's such a huge circle for an untelegraphed global ult, and it effectively zones the entire enemy team. Therein lies his ult's problem: Rumble's Equaliser is hailed as a great zoning tool, but Gangplank's ultimate is far easier to land and can be used from anywhere on the map.

I always ban Gangplank when I can simply because I am not good enough at ADC to handle his cannon barrage allowing Leona's easy engages.

I agree with this, gold generation creates serious item lead problems that are difficult to balance around, especially in the laning phase. Gangplank is especially difficult to deal with because his other abilities allow him to play with more safety than many other top laners, which goes back to his old issues of eking out lane victories through gold generation advantages rather than more interesting engages. While it was a nice touch to keep his plundering theme, it might be better to just cut out the gold generation portion and leave him with his Silver Serpents mechanic.

I think his barrels are, in most circumstances, more or less okay, but what I especially dislike about them is how unpredictable they can be for both Gangplank and his opponent. Crit interaction could be fun, but not in an environment when crits are purely RNG-dependent, and placing so much power on what is essentially random chance screws everyone over (Gangplank can miss a juicy amount of farm simply because he didn't get the crit he needed to last-hit every minion at once, but squishies can find themselves get blown up with 1k+ crit damage barrels). I'm also not the biggest fan of their early health, which can be bypassed by Gangplank by spawning an early barrel next to him and using it to detonate subsequent ones. Not sure how this could get fixed, but revising how they get detonated and how much of a real chance opponents have at disabling them early on could also help him be less of a lane bully (taking down barrels is usually a false choice for melee champions, for example, who are much more liable to just have it detonate in their face).

> his old issues of eking out lane victories through gold generation advantages rather than more interesting engages. 

That's also certainly a thing. In most lanes, you have three basic states:

1) You kill your opponent or have superior trades, forcing him to back and you to gain a Gold lead.

2) You go even with your opponent, meaning you have similar CS and Gold values.

3) You are defeated by your opponent and have a Gold disadvantage.

in Gangplank's case, it's much more difficult to achieve #2, because Gangplank *naturally* has a Gold lead on you. You need to actually deny him CS in order to be on even footing with him. (Same goes with TF.) That's a ridiculous proposition: given 100 CS on both sides, neither side should have an advantage over the other for simply existing. (Mordekaiser does this with duo lanes.)

I agree, and from the looks of it these kinds of laning advantages tend to incur major dysfunctionality in other areas: back when Ashe had her income bonus on her E, she had an abysmal (and quite boring) laning phase to compensate, which ended up forcing her to farm passively. TF has a burst pattern with really low actual burst, and so mostly needs to gank other lanes at opportune moments to make use of his early gold lead. Morde is Morde, so playing him in a duo lane is pretty much punishment in itself, even with the XP bonus, and even Draven to some degree only capitalizes on his bonus gold through champion kills, which avoids the whole passive advantage aspect of bonus income but makes him more binary as a result. By contrast, Gangplank is now a pretty functional champion with the ability to do cool things in lane and scale well thereafter, so there really isn't an innate need for him to earn items faster than others, besides the flavor and pre-existence of his gold bonus. He does need an incentive to use his Q other than for poke, but Silver Serpents are already a good way to encourage that, and if nothing else he could be balanced around a weaker ult, as you mentioned, and stronger Silver Serpent-based upgrades, which would take away some of his free global power and allow him to be shut down more easily.

Champions often stop being played when they received nerfs simply because it takes time to get used to number changes behind the nerf. Not because they aren't strong. GP was still an unquestionably strong pick, but he's also has received some serious number changes in patches in which he gets attention being his barrel count and CD was adjusted among myriads of things. To bring a champion immediately that gets such a shift of power into professional play is downright illogical. 

Ryze is another example of this. When he got his rework v2 (Not his current one), he was unquestionably the strongest top/mid laner in the game, yet you didn't see him for almost a full season. Why? Because it took professional players ages to hit the point where they had his number and combos down. The pros aren't going to play a champion whom they don't have the exact numbers down on.

Not sure how you claim the pros are bad at GP when they are the ones that are the best at the game. Especially considering LCK is the undisputed hands down strongest region, player quality-wise, if a champion starts being picked and played with a build consistently in the LCK, that usually means its a strong champion. They're the ones that discover pretty much everything that everyone else plays. 

Often time, the meta we see in professional play is established or mimicked by the LCK. So if they start spamming a champion with a consistent build, that's usually a strong hint that said champion/build is powerful. Every pro will go to LCK/Korea before worlds for boot camp. Reason being, its the strongest region. 

It's also incredibly ironic that you say Impact didn't have a contribution to the series against Immortals considering he was named the MVP of the BO5. And its also arguable that except for his one solid game on GP, Huni was the reason Immortals lost the series as he swallowed up so much of the teams resources and proceeded to tilt and play poorly with non-meta champions, deja vu to the Spring championship split.

Also, while yes, Huni did play well that one game, Reignover securing a triple inferno buff, basically an AD deathcap for Huni, certainly help him snowball his game. Not taking away from Huni's play, but his success with GP that game was in large part because Reignover pretty much handed him his damage on a silver platter. Impact would have done the same exact thing in his situation. Hell any professional top laner could have done what Huni did in his situation with a triple inferno. Hardly a strong case for good GP game play. 

Even when Impact was playing Gangplank he was playing him quite well, he was absorbing a lot of attention through repeated ganks and he made Immortals expend far too much in try to kill him. It was the rest of his team that didn't play well. 

And that's really whats key about Gangplank in professional play right now: he's so fucking difficult to kill that you need to expend a massive amount of resources into killing him. 

And the kicker is even if you kill him multiple times, because of his safe wave clear, bandit, and his gold generation passive, he's always guaranteed to hit his late game hyper-carry status. You know how the counter-play to late game hyper carries is to focus them down so much that they are crippled to a point where they will never hit that late game power spike? Yeah, absolutely not applicable with GP. See the problem? 

GP's problem is exactly what the OP is talking about: for such a late game hyper-carry champ, his ultimate has insane early-mid global pressure combined with the fact that he generates gold at a rate that's unparalleled to any other champion which leads inevitably to an insane late game that happens earlier then it should, is a recipe for an overly-strong champion. 

Until they address that, he's going to go down the same road as Azir and Kalista.
